MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000535
Special Investigation Intake Date: April 7, 2025
License #: CB630369213
Licensee Group Organization: Judson CS
Licensee Designee: George Winn
Chief Administrator: Michelle Carlton
Agency Name: CHILD SAFE MICHIGAN JUDSON CS
Agency Address: 4410 W 13 MILE RD
ROYAL OAK, MI 48073-6515
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 06/17/2025
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
Section • (3) The agency shall document all the following in the
Description child's record before a change of placement occurs:
• (c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed
with a relative, then the reason why those
placements are not possible.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is court ordered to place child with relatives but has not
done so.
Investigation Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on April 23, 2025. She stated Biological Mother has 4
other children who were previously removed, and parental rights
have been terminated. Youth A was initially placed by Child
Protective Services (CPS) with a relative prior to agency having
case management responsibility. Youth A was removed from
relative placement and placed in a licensed foster home due to
concerns the relative wasn’t taking Youth A to necessary medical
appointments and allowing Biological Mother contact with Youth A
without agency approval or supervision.
FC supervisor stated during recent pretrial hearing CPS worker
testified there are 2 pending MDHHS 5770 Relative Approval &
Placement Safety Screen forms that MDHHS kinship office is
completing. PAFC agency received an email on Monday, April 21,
2025, indicating both forms were approved. MDHHS requested a
team meeting with all involved to discuss the placement options.
She believes one of the options is a fictive kin and the other is a
relative. The team identified concerns with the placement options
and the decision was made to wait until the District Manager from
MDHHS, who was out of the office for the week, was available
and obtain her opinion before a decision is made to ensure the
placement decision is in Youth A’s best interests. In addition, a
putative father has been identified for Youth A. A DNA test was
ordered by the court and results are pending. Putative paternal
grandmother has indicated she would also be interested in
placement if the results of the DNA tests show her son is the
father of Youth A. The agency clarified the relative search is
ongoing as they became aware of potential placement options.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
April 24, 2025. She stated the agency is actively working on
potential relative placement. Upon receiving the case from
MDHHS there were 2 pending 5770’s, one with a relative and one
with fictive kin. She stated there were some concerns that arose
and needed additional consideration and communication with
MDHHS. FCW clarified the most recent court order indicated the
agency must explore relative placement and that is actively
occurring.
Biological Mother was interviewed via telephone on April 24,
2025. She stated during a court hearing held on March 19, 2025,
2

the judge ordered Youth A to be placed with a relative and that
has not occurred. She stated 2 of her relatives have informed the
agency they are interested in placement and has attempted to
contact the agency but there has not been any communication.
Documents reviewed:
• March 19, 2025, court order. Order states agency to
continue to investigate relatives for Youth A and forward
any rejection to AAG to forward to attorneys.
• Reviewed 2 MDHHS 5770 Relative Approval & Placement
Safety Screen forms completed on April 18, 2025, and April
21, 2025. Both relatives were recently approved and being
considered for placement of Youth A.
•
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. In reviewing Youth A’s
MISACWIS case file the most recent court order dated March 19,
2025, states the agency is to investigate potential relative
placement. Based on completed interviews there has been
ongoing effort to investigate appropriate relative placement.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
Section • (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must
Description include all the following:
• (c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
• (i) A comprehensive medical examination,
including a behavioral/mental health and
trauma screening, within 30 calendar days
from the date the child entered into an out-of-
home placement, regardless of the date of the
last physical examination.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Child's initial medical examination was not completed within 30
days of removal.
Investigation Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on April 23, 2025. She stated Youth A was removed
from Biological Mother on March 18, 2025. An initial medical exam
was completed on April 9, 2025, with no concerns noted. FC
supervisor stated Biological Mother was notified of the
appointment beforehand but declined to attend. She was provided
with an update after the appointment.
3

Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
April 24, 2025. She stated Youth A was removed from parental
home on March 18, 2025. She stated an initial medical
appointment occurred on April 9, 2025. A previous appointment
had been set but rescheduled due to foster parents being ill. FCW
stated Biological Mother was notified of and invited to all
scheduled appointments but declined to attend.
Biological Mother was interviewed via telephone on April 24,
2025. She stated the agency was supposed to take Youth A to a
doctor’s appointment and never did. After that she contacted FCW
and was told a different appointment was made. Biological Mother
stated she declined to attend the appointment but acknowledged
the agency does notify her of Youth A’s appointments.
Documents reviewed:
• Youth A’s MISACWIS health profile. Initial medical
appointment occurred on April 9, 2025. Uploaded
documentation from medical provider indicates no concerns
noted.
Analysis The agency is found to be in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case record the
agency completed the initial medical examination within the
required timeframe.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
Section • (1) An agency shall develop service plans with the child,
Description the child's parents or legal guardian, the referring agency,
and other parties involved in providing needed services, or
medical care, unless the agency documents why any of the
entities have not been involved.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not meet with parent and include her in the
development of initial service plan.
Investigation Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on April 23, 2025. She stated FCW met with Biological
Mother either before or after parenting time on April 7, 2025 to
discuss her treatment plan. Youth A came into care under a
permanent custody petition, so services are not court ordered at
this time. There is another court hearing on June 3, 2025, for an
in-person bench trial. The agency is still working on a treatment
4

plan and basic things they can start now. FC supervisor stated
that the treatment plan is still pending supervisor approval and
due to be approved in a few days. Once it is approved Biological
Mother will receive a copy of the treatment plan.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
April 24, 2025. FCW stated she met with Biological Mother during
an FTM and reviewed her childhood, previous removals and
services/resources she may benefit from. In addition, FCW
provided Biological Mother with housing and employment
resources. She stated they went through every aspect of the
treatment plan and service plan during the meeting and Biological
Mother appeared to be receptive.
Biological Mother was interviewed via telephone on April 24,
2025. She stated FCW provided resources for housing. She
stated there has not been any discussion regarding any services
she may need to do or barriers she has to reunification. She
stated she completed a parenting class on her own.
Documents reviewed:
• Youth A’s MISACWIS case file April 7, 2025, social work
contact: “An FTM was held to discuss the ISP. Biological
Mother’s relationship, employment, housing, mental and
physical needs were discussed. Mother does not have a
home or a job at this time but is looking. FCW gave
Biological Mother housing and employment resources.
Biological Mother also needs help paying for her road test
as well as has outstanding tickets in the amount of $2,100”.
• MDHHS 1105 Family Team Meeting Reported dated April
7, 2025. FTM type: ISP Case Service Plan development
signed by FCW and Biological Mother.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case record the
assigned FCW meet with Biological Mother to discuss services,
barriers and include her in the development of the treatment plan
as required.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the c,urrent license status be
continued.
_________4/25/2025___________________________
